emailColumn.title: ipnote: Building AI-Powered International Success

authorInfo.title: About the Author
authorInfo.description: Alex Levkin is the founder of a global intellectual property management platform that connects clients worldwide with local patent attorneys. With over 12 years of experience in IP consulting across the CIS region, he has transformed traditional IP services into a scalable, AI-powered platform serving clients in over 50 countries. His platform addresses the complex challenge of managing intellectual property across multiple jurisdictions through innovative technology and strategic global partnerships.

keyTakeaways.title: Key Takeaways
keyTakeaways.description: This case study reveals how a traditional IP consulting business successfully transformed into a global platform by leveraging AI technology, strategic pivoting during geopolitical challenges, and innovative funding approaches. Key lessons include: the importance of global thinking from day one, the power of AI in solving complex user experience challenges, creative funding through provider partnerships, and the value of targeting expatriate communities for early market validation. The platform's success demonstrates how specialized B2B services can scale globally through technology while maintaining the human expertise that clients value.

emails.subject: From Local Consulting to Global Vision: Why We Chose International Markets from Day One
emails.body:
You asked about how and why we initially entered the international market rather than continuing to focus on the home market. Let me share our somewhat unique journey.

Since 2012, I have been working as a consultant in the CIS, specializing in intellectual property management, registration of trademarks, and patent services. My clients were exclusively companies who needed IP services within the country. As these companies began expanding globally ğŸŒ, we started working with international partners to manage their intellectual property tasks abroad.

Despite the success of this intellectual property consulting business, I always found it somewhat unsatisfying because it wasn't scalable ğŸ“ˆ. This led me to conceptualize a platform that would optimize intellectual property management across different countries. The insight was simple: almost every ambitious startup envisions becoming a large international company operating across multiple markets. Managing IP across dozens of countries is both complicated and expensive ğŸ’°, requiring local patent attorneys in each jurisdiction.

Our platform concept addressed this challenge by connecting clients with local patent attorneys around the world ğŸ—ºï¸ through a single interface, making the process more efficient and cost-effective. Due to the nature of this service, we never had a specific geographic focus for our customer base. From the beginning, we designed our platform to serve clients from any country who needed IP services in any other country.

This global approach is both an advantage and a disadvantage. The disadvantage is that we don't immerse ourselves deeply in any single market's specifics or mentality. The advantage is our ability to serve a truly global client base - we currently have paying clients in more than 50 countries ğŸŒ despite being relatively small in terms of revenue.

To support this global approach, we use a combination of Google Ads, SEO optimization, content marketing, and translations into various local languages ğŸ—£ï¸. We typically create content in one language first, then translate it into different languages to reach a broader audience.

highlight.title: Global-First Strategy: Building Without Borders
highlight.description: Instead of starting locally and expanding later, this company built a global platform from day one. This approach worked because IP management is naturally cross-border - companies need help in many countries, not just their home market. Think of it like building a bridge that connects every country's lawyers with every country's businesses, making complicated legal work simple and accessible.

emails.subject: Navigating Geopolitical Storms: How Crisis Forced Our Strategic Pivot
emails.body:
You asked about our early platform development and how we navigated the challenges of the changing geopolitical landscape.

We began developing our platform in 2021 ğŸš€, initially focusing on building our provider network - patent attorneys and law firms from around the world. Our original strategy assumed we would first onboard our existing clients to generate initial cash flow ğŸ’µ, then gradually expand globally. However, the geopolitical situation in 2022 (the war in Ukraine and subsequent sanctions) completely disrupted this plan.

We quickly realized that onboarding local clients would actually hinder our international growth by making it difficult to attract investment ğŸ“Š. Additionally, new sanctions meant that many international patent attorneys were unwilling to provide services to clients due to reputational risks. Even those willing to work with those clients faced practical challenges as international payment systems became unavailable ğŸ’³.

This forced us to rapidly pivot our strategy. We had already registered a company in the US in 2021, but by 2022, many services had blocked it, rendering it ineffective. We abandoned that entity, established a new company in Armenia ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡², transferred our development team there, and restructured our connections with our country to comply with the new reality.

For our provider network, we took a methodical approach to building global coverage. We identified accredited providers in each country (typically available through official agency websites or professional directories), then implemented aggressive email outreach and LinkedIn campaigns ğŸ“§. We hired a team of four people who managed automated mailings and personally followed up with everyone who responded. Our pitch was straightforward: providers could register on our platform for free ğŸ†“, create a profile, and eventually receive deals with just a commission fee on successful transactions.

The conversion rates varied across different regions, with some cultural and language barriers emerging, but these didn't prevent us from achieving our goal of establishing a baseline of qualified providers in each target country. By the end of this initial phase, we had coverage in at least 100 countries ğŸŒ, starting with the major IP jurisdictions (US, Europe, Asia) and gradually expanding to more specialized markets.

highlight.title: Crisis as Opportunity: When Problems Force Better Solutions
highlight.description: Sometimes bad things happen that force us to make better choices. When war and sanctions made their original plan impossible, this company had to quickly move to a new country and change their strategy. Instead of giving up, they used this crisis to build something even better - a truly global network of lawyers that wasn't dependent on any single country. It's like when a storm destroys your small garden, so you decide to build a greenhouse that can grow plants all year round.

emails.subject: Trust vs. Transactions: The Challenge of Converting Unknown Prospects
emails.body:
You asked about our experience transitioning from building our provider network to acquiring clients, particularly the differences in approach and results.

There was indeed a dramatic difference between provider outreach and client acquisition. With providers, we were essentially offering them a free way to make more money ğŸ’° - a relatively easy sell with high conversion rates. With clients, we were asking them to spend money with an unknown platform lacking established trust - a much harder proposition resulting in significantly lower conversion rates ğŸ“‰.

We tested various approaches including email campaigns and LinkedIn outreach. We saw some replies, calls, and demos, but our conversion to actual deals was extremely low - perhaps one or two transactions in six months â°. The clients who did convert during this period were predominantly expats. The trust factor played a major role here; someone who shared a language and cultural background with us was much more likely to become a client than someone with no prior connection ğŸ¤.

This led us to an important insight that might be valuable for your book: focusing on the CIS community abroad can be a highly effective strategy when entering international markets with a young product ğŸŒ±. These clients understand you better, trust forms more quickly, and they often have connections to the broader business community in their adopted countries. Even today, this segment remains a significant piece of our business.

The Americans we approached would often express enthusiasm during demos, claiming they were ready to buy immediately ğŸ¯, but then would stop responding altogether. This behavioral pattern was quite frustrating and required us to adjust our expectations and follow-up strategies.

Our early client acquisition difficulties were compounded by product usability issues. Even when we managed to drive traffic through advertising, visitors struggled to understand what actions to take on our platform ğŸ¤”. The complex nature of IP services meant that users would get lost, not knowing how to initiate a patent or trademark registration process. While our system worked well if someone guided users through it manually, self-service conversion was nearly non-existent.

highlight.title: The Trust Gap: Why Selling to Strangers is Harder Than Helping Friends
highlight.description: Getting lawyers to join the platform was easy because they got free business. But getting companies to pay money was much harder because they didn't know or trust the platform yet. The company learned that people from their home country living abroad were much more likely to become customers because they shared language and culture. It's like how you're more likely to try a new restaurant if your friend recommends it than if you just see an ad for it.

emails.subject: AI-Powered Breakthrough: How Technology Solved Our User Experience Crisis
emails.body:
You asked about how we evolved our strategy after the initial challenges and what led to our breakthrough moment.

A significant turning point came in 2023 when we integrated AI into our platform ğŸ¤–. While living in California and speaking with various industry contacts, I discovered the potential of implementing an AI assistant to guide users through our complex service offerings.

The impact was transformative âš¡. For the first time, users who weren't personally guided by our team could successfully navigate the platform, discuss their needs with the AI assistant, create appropriate tasks, and receive price quotes from providers, and complete payments ğŸ’³ - all within a single session. This dramatically improved our conversion rates from organic traffic.

This breakthrough shifted our strategic focus toward digital marketing ğŸ“±. With a product that could now convert visitors autonomously, we began investing more heavily in capturing online search traffic. Our approach focused on two primary channels:

Google Ads - Targeting specific search terms related to IP services ğŸ¯
Organic SEO - Building a massive content infrastructure for long-term growth ğŸ“ˆ

We chose these channels specifically because they allow us to target users with clear intent. When someone searches for 'trademark registration in the USA' ğŸ”, we know exactly what they need. This is much more effective than demographic targeting on platforms like Meta, where we can't be certain of user intent.

For our SEO strategy, we implemented an ambitious content approach. We created a separate optimized landing page for each service in each country - with approximately 15 landing pages per country ğŸ“„. We applied this structure across 50 countries and translated everything into 10 languages ğŸ—£ï¸. This resulted in roughly 7,500 landing pages, plus another 500 blog articles also translated into multiple languages. While this seems overwhelming, we managed to create this entire infrastructure for just a few thousand dollars by leveraging GPT for content generation and translation.

This investment is now beginning to pay off as our organic traffic grows exponentially ğŸ“Š. Where we once saw 50 visitors monthly, we're now seeing 250, and we project reaching 1,000 daily visitors within a year.

We're simultaneously running multiple advertising campaigns across different jurisdictions. Through continuous testing and optimization, we've reduced our cost per lead from $350 to $90 in some markets ğŸ’°. These leads convert into one-time clients, and a percentage of those eventually become core clients who may spend $100,000 in a single month.

highlight.title: The Magic of AI: Turning Confusion into Clarity
highlight.description: The company's biggest breakthrough came when they added an AI helper to their website. Before AI, people would visit the site but get confused and leave without buying anything. The AI assistant was like having a smart helper who could answer questions and guide people through the complicated legal process. This simple addition transformed their business from one that needed human salespeople to one that could sell automatically online, making their growth much faster and cheaper.

emails.subject: Creative Funding: How We Turned Our Network into Our Investors
emails.body:
You asked about our approach to funding our marketing efforts and scaling our business globally.

One innovative strategy we've implemented is leveraging our provider network to fund our marketing activities ğŸ’¡. When we began successfully attracting clients through advertising but lacked sufficient capital to scale these efforts, we approached providers in different jurisdictions with a proposition: purchase a subscription to our service (initially priced at $3,000) ğŸ’°, which we would then invest entirely in marketing to bring them leads.

We offered a guarantee - if we didn't deliver leads worth that amount, we would refund the difference ğŸ›¡ï¸. This approach effectively shared the risk of marketing investment with our providers while giving us the capital needed to expand our advertising reach. Over time, as we demonstrated results, we've been able to increase these subscription prices ğŸ“ˆ. We started selling annual subscriptions for $1,000, but our most recent offer was priced at $13,000.

This strategy has been particularly effective for our marketplace model, where maintaining balance between supply (providers) and demand (clients) is crucial âš–ï¸. Unlike a city-based marketplace like food delivery or ride-sharing where you need to balance restaurants and customers within a single city, our 'city' is the entire world ğŸŒ. Our primary focus is facilitating cross-border transactions - connecting clients from one country with providers in another.

This global nature creates unique scaling challenges. We can't just focus on building a user base in one market; we need sufficient variety across all markets to make our cross-border model work effectively ğŸ”„. For example, we don't want to just connect American clients with American lawyers - we want to connect American clients with lawyers from Europe, Japan, and China ğŸŒ; Japanese clients with lawyers from Europe, China, and Brazil; and so on.

While approximately 30-40% of our client base consists of US-based companies ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸, our focus is less on geography and more on client profiles - identifying companies at the right stage, in the right industry, with the right IP experience. These ideal clients can be found anywhere from America to Argentina ğŸŒ.

highlight.title: Smart Money: Making Partners Pay for Growth
highlight.description: Instead of asking banks or investors for money, this company had a clever idea: they asked the lawyers on their platform to pay for marketing that would bring the lawyers more customers. It's like if you wanted to start a farmer's market but had no money for advertising, so you asked the farmers to chip in for ads that would bring more shoppers to buy their vegetables. The farmers win because they get more customers, and you win because you get money to grow the market.

emails.subject: Scaling Smart: Building Teams and Targeting Enterprise Markets
emails.body:
You asked about our approach to hiring internationally and our future strategic direction.

In the early stages, we experimented with international hiring ğŸŒ. In 2021, we brought on a CEO for Europe who was multilingual and had experience working with international companies.

However, this proved premature given our product's stage of development âš ï¸. It was essentially a waste of time and money because our product wasn't ready for enterprise-level sales.

Since then, we've reconsidered our approach to international hiring. Currently, we're operating primarily with a local team and focusing on small businesses and early-stage startups ğŸš€, which can still be quite profitable in our industry. As we raise our ambitions to target larger enterprise clients, we'll definitely need to hire local sales representatives in different jurisdictions.

We recently attended a conference in Germany ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡ª where we connected with representatives from large European businesses - companies that spend hundreds of millions of dollars on intellectual property annually ğŸ’°. While these enterprise clients are currently beyond our immediate reach, we're laying the groundwork for future relationships. When we're ready to pursue this segment more aggressively, we plan to hire experienced European professionals from the IP industry who can leverage their existing networks and credibility ğŸ¤.

For enterprise sales, we'll follow a more traditional approach: local representation, local marketing, local PR, conference attendance, in-person meetings, and direct calls ğŸ“. However, getting to this stage requires us to first succeed with our current, more unconventional approach.

We've also recently begun investing in PR activities to build our reputation ğŸ“°, particularly in the American market, which remains our primary focus due to its size and spending power. The US market is substantially larger than others in terms of patent volume (second only to China, though China's patents are often lower quality) and service costs ğŸ’µ. A single IP transaction in America can generate $25,000 in fees, while European, Asian, and African clients typically spend significantly less.

Throughout our journey, we've found LinkedIn to be a critical communication channel ğŸ’¼ since most of our target audience is active there. We're now expanding our presence through expert interviews, press releases, and thought leadership content to establish credibility in this specialized field.

highlight.title: Growing Up: From Small Fish to Big Pond Strategy
highlight.description: The company learned an important lesson: don't try to catch big fish before you know how to fish properly. They hired expensive salespeople too early when their product wasn't ready for big companies. Now they're focusing on smaller businesses first to perfect their approach, then they'll hire local experts in each country to help them sell to giant companies. It's like learning to cook simple meals perfectly before trying to become a chef at a fancy restaurant.
